It effectively supports and complements existing IT systems, enhances digital efficiency in enterprises, and assists in building an all-in-one collaborative platform, allowing employees to focus on their work and simplifying their tasks, while enabling IT personnel to develop agilely and enjoy a better user experience.Integrating enterprise systems with the Lark Open Platform can quickly break down barriers between sy
https://open.larksuite.com/document/clie.full_content:
Developer GuidesPlatform IntroductionLark Open Capabilities IntroductionLark Open Capabilities IntroductionCopy PageLast updated on 2023-09-13The contents of this articleUse CasesEfficient business message circulation with "bots + message cards"Rich open capabilities and components that support diverse integration needs of enterprisesServices and SupportWhat can Lark's capabilities bring to enterprises?Lark's comprehensive and in-depth open capabilities serve as a hub of information and an entry point for businesses, integrating with existing IT ecosystems in enterprises. It effectively supports and complements existing IT systems, enhances digital efficiency in enterprises, and assists in building an all-in-one collaborative platform, allowing employees to focus on their work and simplifying their tasks, while enabling IT personnel to develop agilely and enjoy a better user experience.Integrating enterprise systems with the Lark Open Platform can quickly break down barriers between systems and facilitate more efficient information transmission. Enterprises can utilize multiple Lark module capabilities such as documents, address books, messages, and user cards in both existing and new applications, enabling efficient collaboration beyond Lark.We provide diverse integration solutions for enterprises to meet their customization needs and address complex business scenarios. We support integration with CRM, OA, ERP, finance, and other systems, helping bridge the gap between business systems and users, and empowering enterprises to achieve digital transformation.Use CasesEfficient business message circulation with "bots + message cards"Lark bots can be integrated with Lark Calendar, Approval, Cloud Documents, third-party mainstream business systems, and enterprise-built systems. By sending message cards to users, various types of application notifications and alerts can be aggregated in Lark. For example, it can integrate with existing business systems in an enterprise to send monitoring alerts, reminders for to-do tasks, company event notifications, daily data reports, stock alerts, and more.Message cards are a type of message that can contain rich text content and interactive functions. With message cards, you can:Use the rich text styles and graphic layout modules provided by message cards to send visually appealing cards, such as eye-catching notifications and articles with images, ensuring important information reaches users effectively.Use the interactive components provided by message cards to allow users to perform system operations such as approval, voting, and alert handling directly in the chat session without leaving Lark.

                                         Replay
                                        To help developers visualize the completion of message cards, we provide a Message Card Builder tool. It allows for easy drag-and-drop addition of module components, providing a smooth experience. The tool also offers a rich library of card templates, including templates for various scenarios, enabling one-click activation for convenient and efficient use.Rich open capabilities and components that support diverse integration needs of enterprisesEnterprises can call multiple Lark module capabilities, including Lark Docs, multidimensional spreadsheets, address books, messages, tasks, user cards, and more, in their existing systems and new applications. The opened and supported capabilities can be found in the "Open Capability List" on the Open Platform official website.In addition to the extensive server API, Lark also provides the ability to develop various types of applications to suit customized needs.An Lark application is a carrier for developers to provide services to their users. It is usually presented in the form of bots, webapps, gadgets, etc. It also has access to the full scope of the platform, paving the way for more enhanced, custom, and powerful experiences within Lark. Some tips on makeing the choices:Bots: interact with users in chat, retrieve data, send/respond to messages, access Lark OpenAPIsWebapp : frequent content updates, existing h5 app migrationGadgets/miniapp: complex modules, require phone/Lark functions, native and smooth user experienceThe various applications commonly seen in the Workbench are Lark gadgets or Lark web applications, such as approval, and Lark Help Center. Lark can integrate various types of applications:App TypeBotH5Workbench BlockGadgetDemoApplicable ScenariosApplications that interact with users in chat, automatically send messages to users or groups, respond to users' messages and manage groups.Quickly integrate existing web applications, then users can quickly access them without logging.Add data charts, text and pictures and other information to the workbench.Apps that can run in the Lark client and call Lark components to achieve a native-level experience.Dev ToolsPurely server-side development, with Message Card Builder providedLark Developer Tools IDELark Developer Tools IDELark Developer Tools IDEDev ResourcesDevelop a botH5 JS APIBlock introductionComponents & APIsFor more information, refer to the Introduction to Application Capabilities.Services and SupportObtain Technical Support: Click the technical support button at the bottom right of any page on the official website to consult any questions you encounter during development. Technical professionals will assist you one-on-one to solve your problems.Provide Feedback on Document Issues: If you discover any errors in the development documentation, you can directly provide feedback by selecting the text on the document page. The feedback will be sent directly to the document authors, and you will receive notifications from Lark once the issue is resolved.Get updates on Lark's open capabilities: Explore newly released capabilities: ChangelogJoin the developer community: If you want to have access to the latest capabilities for beta testing and connect with other enterprise developers, feel free to join the Lark Developer Community.FeedbackNext:Application typesNeed help with a problem?Submit feedback

https://open.larksuite.com/document/serv.title: Process overview
https://open.larksuite.com/document/serv.content_preview: Server APIAPI Call GuideCalling ProcessProcess overviewProcess overviewCopy PageLast updated on 2024-02-18Process overviewThe APIs provided by Lark Open Platform follow the RESTful style, and the format of the request URL is as follows:The process of calling server APIs is illustrated in the following diagram:Create apps. In the Developer Console, create custom apps or store apps according to actual needs.Only users with ISV qualifications can create store apps. For more information , see How to join Lark Open Platform as an ISV.Obtain an access token. Lark Open Platform provides various types of access tokens, which represent different resource access permissions. When calling APIs, the access token needs to be included in the HTTP header to access resources within the defined permissions.Apply for API scopes. If you want to call the API, you must get the scope to call the interface first. If it involves accessing sensitive fields, you also need to get the scope to access sensitive fi
https://open.larksuite.com/document/serv.full_content: Server APIAPI Call GuideCalling ProcessProcess overviewProcess overviewCopy PageLast updated on 2024-02-18Process overviewThe APIs provided by Lark Open Platform follow the RESTful style, and the format of the request URL is as follows:The process of calling server APIs is illustrated in the following diagram:Create apps. In the Developer Console, create custom apps or store apps according to actual needs.Only users with ISV qualifications can create store apps. For more information , see How to join Lark Open Platform as an ISV.Obtain an access token. Lark Open Platform provides various types of access tokens, which represent different resource access permissions. When calling APIs, the access token needs to be included in the HTTP header to access resources within the defined permissions.Apply for API scopes. If you want to call the API, you must get the scope to call the interface first. If it involves accessing sensitive fields, you also need to get the scope to access sensitive fields.(Optional) Configure data permissions. When an app requests permissions for certain APIs (e.g.,  Contacts, Lark HR Enterprise Edition), it needs to configure the corresponding data permissions and submit them for review. The permissions take effect after the review is approved, enabling successful data retrieval through API calls. Otherwise, an authorization error will be returned when invoking the API.(Optional) Set IP whitelist. To enhance app security, you can set an IP whitelist for your app. Only requests originating from whitelisted IP addresses will be responded to by the Lark Open Platform. Otherwise, the requests will be rejected.Call the API. After completing the above steps, you can call the open API. Users can refer to the API documentation to understand the specific functions of the API.FeedbackPrevious:Message ShortcutsNext:Obtain access tokensNeed help with a problem?Submit feedback

https://open.larksuite.com/document/uAjL.title: OpenAPI MCP overview
https://open.larksuite.com/document/uAjL.content_preview: MCPOpenAPI MCP IntegrationOpenAPI MCP overviewOpenAPI MCP overviewCopy PageLast updated on 2025-07-01The contents of this articleFeaturesTypical use casesSupported openAPIMCP tool naming schemeOpenAPI MCP overviewOpenAPI MCP Tool (hereinafter referred to as "MCP Tool") can help you quickly integrate AI agents with Lark's open capabilities, enabling automated scenarios such as document processing, conversation management, and calendar scheduling based on agents.FeaturesThe MCP Tool uses the MCP (Model Context Protocol) protocol to connect with the Lark Open Platform, providing a rich set of OpenAPI tools that cover Lark's core functions (such as messages, groups, calendars, Base apps, etc.). It also supports application access tokens (tenant_access_token) and user access tokens (user_access_token) to ensure secure and controllable API calls. The features of the MCP Tool are as follows:Provides a simple and easy-to-use command line interface for quick configuration and startup.Supports v
https://open.larksuite.com/document/uAjL.full_content: MCPOpenAPI MCP IntegrationOpenAPI MCP overviewOpenAPI MCP overviewCopy PageLast updated on 2025-07-01The contents of this articleFeaturesTypical use casesSupported openAPIMCP tool naming schemeOpenAPI MCP overviewOpenAPI MCP Tool (hereinafter referred to as "MCP Tool") can help you quickly integrate AI agents with Lark's open capabilities, enabling automated scenarios such as document processing, conversation management, and calendar scheduling based on agents.FeaturesThe MCP Tool uses the MCP (Model Context Protocol) protocol to connect with the Lark Open Platform, providing a rich set of OpenAPI tools that cover Lark's core functions (such as messages, groups, calendars, Base apps, etc.). It also supports application access tokens (tenant_access_token) and user access tokens (user_access_token) to ensure secure and controllable API calls. The features of the MCP Tool are as follows:Provides a simple and easy-to-use command line interface for quick configuration and startup.Supports various configuration methods, adapting to different usage scenarios.Seamlessly integrates with mainstream AI tools (such as Trae, Cursor, Claude).After configuring the application information, the application access credentials can be obtained automatically; after logging into the MCP and completing user authentication, the user access credentials can be obtained automatically, with support for automatic refresh.Typical use casesAI will plan based on the actual input prompt and invoke different OpenAPIs, so the permissions that the application needs to open may vary.Scenario ExamplePre-ConfigurationTrae Running ExampleInitialize Project Management Base appsApplication Capability: BotApplication Permissions:  View, comment, edit and manage Base appsCreate Group Chat, Add Members and Send Lark CardApplication Capability: BotApplication Permissions:Retrieve and update group informationSend messages as an applicationOthers: Ensure all members in the group are within the application's visibility scope. Refer to Configure Application Availability.Summarize Group Messages and Record in Base appsApplication Capability: BotApplication Permissions:Retrieve all messages in the group (sensitive permission)Create Base appsAdd new data tablesAdd new recordsOthers: Bot is in the group chatGrant Base apps Permissions to Group MembersApplication Capability: Enable bot capabilityApplication Permissions:  View group membersView, comment, edit and manage Base appsOthers: Bot in group chat; Bot has management permissions for the Base appsSupported openAPIYou can check tools to get the list of OpenAPI supported by the MCP Tool on the Lark Open Platform. You can also determine if an API is supported within the MCP Tool through the API documentation. For example, open an API development document, such as Send Message. If there is a "Try it out" button, it indicates that the API is available within the MCP Tool.APIs in grayscale (i.e., APIs marked as Limited access at the beginning of the API documentation) are temporarily not supported in the MCP tool.APIs related to image or file upload/download are temporarily not supported within the MCP tool.MCP tool naming schemeThe MCP Tool follows the naming scheme of biz.version.resource.method, consistent with the method naming of the server-side Node SDK. You can obtain the name of an OpenAPI in the MCP Tool in the following way:In the API documentation, click Try it out and check the Node SDK sample code. The function after the client method is the name of the API in the MCP Tool. For example, as shown in the figure below, the name of the Send Message API is im.v1.message.create.FeedbackPrevious:requestAuthCodeNext:Develop OpenAPI MCP smart assistantNeed help with a problem?Submit feedback
